Award.AwardTitle: International Collaboration in Chemistry: Single-molecule FRET
Award.AbstractNarration:
This International Collaboration in Chemistry award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation supports Dr. Scott Blanchard, from the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College of Cornell University, to study a mechanism of translation control whereby elements typically residing within the 5'-untranslated region of messenger RNA (mRNA) bind small-molecule metabolites to control gene expression. Such elements are generally referred to as riboswitch domains. The work includes an international collaboration with Dr. Ronald Micura, from the Leopold-Franzens University (Innsbruck, Austria). Dr. Micura's work is supported by the Fonds zur Forderung der wissenshaftlichen Forschung (FWF) in Austria.

A critical aspect of gene expression in all cells is the translation of mRNA templates into specific protein molecules that carry out a broad array of essential life processes. Translation of mRNA is carried out by the ribosome, a two subunit RNA-protein assembly composed of more than fifty individual gene products. Control of gene expression at the level of translation, which is essential to cell survival, can be mediated by numerous mechanisms. The goal of the research is to understand which specific steps in the translation process are affected by the riboswitch response to small-molecule binding. To achieve the goal, the research team will engage a battery of physical and organic chemistry initiatives that will directly image riboswitch-mediated regulation of ribosome-catalyzed translation at the single-molecule scale. In so doing, the team will explore fundamental aspects of the riboswitch regulation mechanism with a special emphasis on the dynamic properties of the system and how such features are regulated by ligand/metabolite binding interactions.

The international collaborative research proposed is designed to provide an opportunity for undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate students from distinct research programs to receive interdisciplinary training in organic chemistry and single-molecule fluorescence. This experience will enable the development of new biophysical approaches and experimental techniques for single-molecule research that can be generally applied to the imaging of dynamic life processes at the molecular scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cellular protein synthesis is carried out by the ribosome, a two subunit RNA-protein assembly that directionally translates the nucleotide sequence of cellular messenger RNAs (mRNAs) into protein using aminoacylated transfer RNA (tRNA) substrates. While the biochemical components and basic framework of the translation process are known, the mechanistic determinants of translation control remain poorly understood. In this research initiative we sought to gain a quantitative, mechanistic understanding of a newly discovered means of translation control in bacterial cells: the riboswitch. Riboswitches are regulatory elements present in cellular mRNAs that adopt alternative structural folds in response to the binding of specific small-molecule metabolites. Understanding how riboswitches can control the expression of the gene products in which they are present by providing a signal to turn “ON” or “OFF” gene expression in response to metabolite binding can ultimately be leveraged for both molecular engineering and therapeutic purposes. During the funding period, a series of biochemical, structural and single-molecule investigations of evolutionarily distinct riboswitch elements were performed that enabled us to gain a deeper mechanistic understanding of how metabolite-riboswitch interactions regulate ribosome binding to mRNA. These studies also help us to establish the means to site-specifically label the ribosome, riboswitch and metabolites with organic fluorophores without perturbing function in order to directly assess the correlation between temporal changes in the riboswitch dynamics and the efficiency of translation initiation. These efforts, carried out as a collaborative, international research project linked through the National Science foundation for International Collaborations in Chemistry between the Blanchard laboratory at Weill Cornell Medical College and the laboratory of Dr. Ronald Micura, from the Leopold-Franzens University in Innsbruck, Austria, led to two collaborative bodies of work that were published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Science. Additional publications focused on delineating the paradigms of molecular recognition by which small-molecule effectors control translation initiation are currently in preparation.
